Desmond Duggan

About

Currently, I study Systems Engineering and Computer Science at Washington University in St. Louis. In the last three years, I discovered passions that include entreprenuership, technology, and fitness.

Outside of class, I row six days per week with the Washington University men's varsity crew team. We compete in all major regattas in the midwestern and eastern regions of the United States. In addition, as the president of the team, I ensure the safe transportation of our equipment and team members, lead the executive board, and manage our relations with the St. Louis community.

I am also the director of wute.vc, an organization that hosts speakers in venture capital and entrepreneurship for the Washington University community. We are the primary application processor for a startup accelerator for wustl students called WuStart@OpenDNS.

In my spare time, I enjoy building web and mobile applications, tasting new wines, and camping.

Next fall I will be working full-time at the Accenture Technology Labs in San Jose, CA.

Selected Work

CELect Consulting Program

In fall 2013, I was accepted to and participated in the CELect at the T-Rex program in the Olin School of Business at Wash U. For 10 weeks, I consulted a startup called Farmplicity with a team of three other students.

Initially, the project scope was to complete an industry analysis, but we expanded to project to include an expansion strategy. We met with Farmplicity several times to understand the company, and at the end of the 10 weeks, my team presented our results at the T-Rex startup incubator in downtown St. Louis.

Systems Engineering Lab

In this class, I paired with 2 other engineering students to model and control a real robotic system using Systems Engineering Control Theory.

We used a combination of Matlab and Simulink to simulate the robotic system on the computer. After we ensured our controllers worked in a simulated environment, we downloaded the controller to the real system and experimented with it. Afer adjusting our parameters to account for inefficiencies in the real system, we successfully controlled the system!
